It is the artist's responsibility to portray the ideal—those who are whole, strong, and unimpaired. When we see these representations in galleries, on screens, and in public spaces, we are reminded of what it truly means to be human: to move with grace, to work with our hands, to express ourselves fully, and to live life without limitations.

It should not suggest that a broken body is the same as a whole one.

By honoring the able-bodied through my art, I help society understand what it should value most: independence, mobility, strength, and the full expression of human potential. That is the true role of art in shaping societal attitudes. To reflect the best of humanity, not the flawed version.
